results:
Based on the search results, I can provide information about the influence of Don Quixote on Polish literature, particularly in relation to Sienkiewicz, Mickiewicz, Żeromski, and Romanticism.

The search revealed several important connections between Don Quixote and Polish literature:

## Don Quixote's Influence on Polish Literature

In Polish literature, there are many examples of such Don Quixotes. Most characters of idealists can probably be found in romantic literature. Adam Mickiewicz was a creator who created many interesting characters of dreamers and idealists.

### Connection to Polish Romanticism

Most characters of idealists can probably be found in romantic literature. The socio-political situation at that time favored the creation of just such characters.(no content)Adam Mickiewicz is one of the most important figures in Polish literature, and his work significantly influenced the development of romanticism in Poland. Adam Mickiewicz is considered the creator of Polish romanticism.

### Mickiewicz and Don Quixote Idealism

Adam Mickiewicz was a creator who created many interesting characters of dreamers and idealists. He already in "Oda do młodości" presented the young generation full of plans and lofty ideals.(no content)They do not agree with the existing world and the shape of reality. As evidenced by the words: "obszar gnuśności zalany odmętem- to ziemia." They do not agree with the world as created by the old.

### Don Quixote as a Universal Symbol

Don Quixote can be called the idealist of all time. This is a character from a 17th-century novel written by Cervantes. Don Quixote is an example of an idealist who wants to heal the world and destroy evil.(no content)Don Quixote became a symbolic figure in culture – a donquixote is what we call an idealist who doesn't take reality into account, a dreamer who wants to fix the world, even though others mock him.

### The Broader Impact on Polish Literary Idealism

The search results indicate that every era has its own Don Quixotes, and Polish romanticism, particularly through Mickiewicz's work, created many characters that embodied the Don Quixote archetype of the idealistic dreamer fighting against reality.

While the search didn't provide specific detailed information about Sienkiewicz and Żeromski's direct connections to Don Quixote, it clearly establishes how the figure of Don Quixote as an idealistic dreamer became a literary archetype that influenced Polish romantic literature, particularly through Mickiewicz's creation of similar characters who fight for noble ideals despite facing an often hostile reality.
